Danish: 1. kapitel
English: — CHAPTER ONE —

Danish: Drengen, der ikke kunne slås ihjel
English: The Boy Who Lived

Danish: Hr. og fru Dursley fra Ligustervænget nummer fire var ganske stolte over, at de var helt og aldeles normale.
English: Mr and Mrs Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much.

Danish: Det var de sidste mennesker, man ville mistænke for at være involveret i mærkelige eller mystiske affærer; de var ganske enkelt af den type mennesker, som ikke tolererer nogen slinger i valsen, hvad ordentlig livsførelse angår.
English: They were the last people you’d expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious, because they just didn’t hold with such nonsense.

Danish: Hr. Dursley var direktør for en stor virksomhed ved navn Grunnings. Den fremstillede drilbor.
English: Mr Dursley was the director of a firm called Grunnings, which made drills.

Danish: Han var en stor, tyk mand, næsten uden nogen hals, men med et kæmpemæssigt overskæg.
English: He was a big, beefy man with hardly any neck, although he did have a very large moustache.

Danish: Fru Dursley var mager og blond; hendes hals var til gengæld omtrent dobbelt så lang som almindelige menneskers, hvilket var meget praktisk for hende, eftersom hun brugte megen tid på at udspionere sine naboer over havehækken.
English: Mrs Dursley was thin and blonde and had nearly twice the usual amount of neck, which came in very useful as she spent so much of her time craning over garden fences, spying on the neighbours.

Danish: Parret havde en lille dreng ved navn Dudley. I deres øjne fandtes hans lige ikke i hele den vide verden.
English: The Dursleys had a small son called Dudley and in their opinion there was no finer boy anywhere.

Danish: Hr. og fru Dursley var velstående og havde alt, hvad de kunne ønske sig, men i tilgift havde de også en hemmelighed, og deres største skræk var, at nogen skulle afsløre den.
English: The Dursleys had everything they wanted, but they also had a secret, and their greatest fear was that somebody would discover it.

Danish: De mente ikke, at de ville kunne bære, at nogen opdagede det med Potter-familien.
English: They didn’t think they could bear it if anyone found out about the Potters.

Danish: Fru Potter var fru Dursleys søster, som hun ikke havde set i mange år. Faktisk lod fru Dursley, som om hun slet ikke havde nogen søster, for denne søster og hendes uduelige mand kunne slet ikke leve op til familien Dursleys standard.
English: Mrs Potter was Mrs Dursley’s sister, but they hadn’t met for several years; in fact, Mrs Dursley pretended she didn’t have a sister, because her sister and her good-for-nothing husband were as unDursleyish as it was possible to be.

Danish: Hr. og fru Dursley gøs ved tanken om, hvad naboerne mon ville sige, hvis Potter-familien kom anstigende til deres kvarter.
English: The Dursleys shuddered to think what the neighbours would say if the Potters arrived in the street.

Danish: Dursley-familien vidste, at Potter-familien også havde en lille dreng, men de havde aldrig set ham.
English: The Dursleys knew that the Potters had a small son, too, but they had never even seen him.

Danish: Denne dreng var en anden god grund til at holde dem på afstand; det ville nemlig være en ulykke, hvis Dudley kom til at mænge sig med sådan en knægt.
English: This boy was another good reason for keeping the Potters away; they didn’t want Dudley mixing with a child like that.

Danish: Da hr. og fru Dursley vågnede på den triste, grå torsdag, hvor vores historie begynder, var der ingen varsler fra den overskyede himmel udenfor om, at mærkværdige og mystiske hændelser snart ville finde sted over hele landet.
English: When Mr and Mrs Dursley woke up on the dull, grey Tuesday our story starts, there was nothing about the cloudy sky outside to suggest that strange and mysterious things would soon be happening all over the country.

Danish: Hr. Dursley nynnede, idet han klædte sig på og udvalgte sit mest kedelige slips som kronen på værket. Fru Dursley sladrede lystigt løs, mens hun kæmpede for at få sat den skrigende Dudley i hans høje stol.
English: Mr Dursley hummed as he picked out his most boring tie for work and Mrs Dursley gossiped away happily as she wrestled a screaming Dudley into his high chair.

Danish: Ingen af dem lagde mærke til en stor brun ugle, der baskede forbi vinduet.
English: None of them noticed a large tawny owl flutter past the window.

Danish: Klokken halv ni tog hr. Dursley sin mappe, klappede fru Dursley på kinden og forsøgte at kysse Dudley farvel, men ramte ved siden af, fordi Dudley nu var midt i et hysterisk anfald og kastede sin havregrød mod væggen.
English: At half past eight, Mr Dursley picked up his briefcase, pecked Mrs Dursley on the cheek and tried to kiss Dudley goodbye but missed, because Dudley was now having a tantrum and throwing his cereal at the walls.

Danish: „Den lille bandit,“ klukkede hr. Dursley, idet han gik ud af huset.
English: ‘Little tyke,’ chortled Mr Dursley as he left the house.

Danish: Han satte sig ind i sin bil og bakkede ud ad indkørslen.
English: He got into his car and backed out of number four’s drive.

Danish: Det var ved vejens første sving, at han opdagede det første tegn på noget mærkværdigt – en kat i færd med at læse et kort.
English: It was on the corner of the street that he noticed the first sign of something peculiar – a cat reading a map.

Danish: Et kort øjeblik fattede hr. Dursley slet ikke, hvad det var, han havde set – så drejede han hovedet med et sæt for at se bedre efter.
English: For a second, Mr Dursley didn’t realise what he had seen – then he jerked his head around to look again.

Danish: Der stod ganske rigtigt en stribet kat i svinget, men den var så sandelig ikke i besiddelse af et kort.
English: There was a tabby cat standing on the corner of Privet Drive, but there wasn’t a map in sight.

Danish: Hvad havde han dog tænkt på? Det måtte være det grådisede lys, der havde spillet ham et puds.
English: What could he have been thinking of? It must have been a trick of the light.

Danish: Hr. Dursley blinkede endnu en gang med øjnene og stirrede på katten.
English: Mr Dursley blinked and stared at the cat.

Danish: Katten stirrede tilbage.
English: It stared back.

Danish: Da hr. Dursley kørte rundt om hjørnet og videre hen ad gaden, holdt han øje med katten i bakspejlet.
English: As Mr Dursley drove around the corner and up the road, he watched the cat in his mirror.

Danish: Nu stod den og læste skiltet, hvorpå der stod Ligustervænget – nej, den kiggede på skiltet; katte kan jo ikke læse hverken skilte eller kort.
English: It was now reading the sign that said Privet Drive – no, looking at the sign; cats couldn’t read maps or signs.

Danish: Hr. Dursley rystede på hovedet ad sig selv og besluttede sig for at glemme alt om katten.
English: Mr Dursley gave himself a little shake and put the cat out of his mind.

Danish: Idet han kørte videre ind mod byen, tænkte han ikke på andet end en stor ordre drilbor, som han håbede at få i hus den næste dag.
English: As he drove towards town he thought of nothing except a large order of drills he was hoping to get that day.

Danish: Men da han nåede byens udkant, blev ordren om de mange drilbor skubbet ud af hans tanker på grund af noget andet.
English: But on the edge of town, drills were driven out of his mind by something else.

Danish: Han sad fast i den sædvanlige morgen-trafikprop og kunne ikke lade være med at bemærke, at der var usædvanligt mange mærkeligt klædte mennesker på færde.
English: As he sat in the usual morning traffic jam, he couldn’t help noticing that there seemed to be a lot of strangely dressed people about.

Danish: Folk i kapper.
English: People in cloaks.

Danish: Hr. Dursley kunne ikke fordrage folk, der klædte sig mærkeligt på – de løjerlige kostumer, som en del unge mennesker yndede! Han tænkte, at dette måske var en ny tåbelig modedille.
English: Mr Dursley couldn’t bear people who dressed in funny clothes – the get-ups you saw on young people! He supposed this was some stupid new fashion.

Danish: Han trommede med fingrene på rattet, og hans øjne fæstnede sig ved en hel flok af disse originaler, der stod ganske nær ved. De hviskede sammen, tilsyneladende i stor ophidselse.
English: He drummed his fingers on the steering wheel and his eyes fell on a huddle of these weirdos standing quite close by. They were whispering excitedly together.

Danish: Hr. Dursley opdagede forarget, at det slet ikke var unge mennesker; tænk engang, den mand i den smaragdgrønne kappe kunne se ud til at være ældre end han selv! Han var sandelig ikke ked af det!
English: Mr Dursley was enraged to see that a couple of them weren’t young at all; why, that man had to be older than he was, and wearing an emerald-green cloak! The nerve of him!

Danish: Men så slog det hr. Dursley, at dette måske var et eller andet fjollet velgørenhedsarrangement – de mærkeligt klædte mennesker kunne godt se ud, som om de var ved at samle ind til et eller andet formål ... Ja, sådan måtte det hænge sammen.
English: But then it struck Mr Dursley that this was probably some silly stunt – these people were obviously collecting for something … yes, that would be it.

Danish: Trafikken bevægede sig igen fremad, og få minutter senere kørte hr. Dursley ind på Grunnings parkeringsplads. Hans tanker kredsede igen om drilbor.
English: The traffic moved on, and a few minutes later, Mr Dursley arrived in the Grunnings car park, his mind back on drills.

Danish: Hr. Dursley sad altid med ryggen til vinduet i sit kontor på niende etage.
English: Mr Dursley always sat with his back to the window in his office on the ninth floor.

Danish: Hvis han havde siddet, så han kunne kigge ud ad vinduet, ville han sikkert ikke have været i stand til at koncentrere sig om sine drilbor denne morgen.
English: If he hadn’t, he might have found it harder to concentrate on drills that morning.

Danish: Han så slet ikke uglerne, der susede forbi her ved højlys dag, men det gjorde til gengæld folk på gaderne: De stod og stirrede med åben mund, mens de pegede på alle uglerne, der fløj omkring over hovederne på dem.
English: He didn’t see the owls swooping past in broad daylight, though people down in the street did; they pointed and gazed open-mouthed as owl after owl sped overhead.

Danish: Mange havde ikke engang set en ugle ved nattetide.
English: Most of them had never seen an owl even at night-time.

Danish: Men hvad hr. Dursley angik, så tilbragte han en ganske normal uglefri formiddag.
English: Mr Dursley, however, had a perfectly normal, owl-free morning.

Danish: Han råbte ad fem forskellige medarbejdere.
English: He yelled at five different people.

Danish: Han foretog flere vigtige telefonopkald og råbte lidt mere ved disse lejligheder.
English: He made several important telephone calls and shouted a bit more.

Danish: Han var i højt humør indtil frokostid, hvor han følte trang til at strække benene og gå over på den anden side af gaden for at købe sig en bolle hos bageren.
English: He was in a very good mood until lunch-time, when he thought he’d stretch his legs and walk across the road to buy himself a bun from the baker’s opposite.

Danish: Han havde glemt alt om de kappeklædte, indtil han passerede en hel flok, der stod ved bagerbutikken.
English: He’d forgotten all about the people in cloaks until he passed a group of them next to the baker’s.

Danish: Han gloede rasende på dem, idet han gik forbi.
English: He eyed them angrily as he passed.

Danish: Han vidste ikke hvorfor, men de gjorde ham ilde til mode.
English: He didn’t know why, but they made him uneasy.

Danish: Denne flok stod også og hviskede ophidset, men han kunne ikke se en eneste raslebøsse.
English: This lot were whispering excitedly, too, and he couldn’t see a single collecting tin.

Danish: Da han havde købt sig en stor cremebolle og passerede flokken på vej tilbage, hørte han nogle løsrevne sætninger af deres samtale.
English: It was on his way back past them, clutching a large doughnut in a bag, that he caught a few words of what they were saying.

Danish: „Familien Potter, det er rigtigt, det har jeg også hørt ...“
English: ‘The Potters, that’s right, that’s what I heard –’

Danish: „Ja, deres søn, Harry ...“
English: ‘– yes, their son, Harry –’

Danish: Hr. Dursley standsede brat op. Bange anelser skyllede ind over ham.
English: Mr Dursley stopped dead. Fear flooded him.

Danish: Han kiggede tilbage på den hviskende flok, som om han skulle til at sige noget til dem, men fortrød det igen.
English: He looked back at the whisperers as if he wanted to say something to them, but thought better of it.

Danish: Han løb over gaden, skyndte sig op til sit kontor, snerrede til sin sekretær, at hun ikke skulle bryde sig om at forstyrre ham, greb telefonen og havde næsten tastet nummeret hjem til sig selv, da han kom på andre tanker.
English: He dashed back across the road, hurried up to his office, snapped at his secretary not to disturb him, seized his telephone and had almost finished dialling his home number when he changed his mind.

Danish: Han lagde røret på igen og strøg sit overskæg, mens han tænkte, så det knagede ... nej, han var bare fjollet.
English: He put the receiver back down and stroked his moustache, thinking … no, he was being stupid.

Danish: Potter var da et temmelig ordinært navn. Han var sikker på, at mange mennesker med efternavnet Potter også havde en søn ved navn Harry.
English: Potter wasn’t such an unusual name. He was sure there were lots of people called Potter who had a son called Harry.

Danish: Nu hvor han tænkte nærmere efter, var han slet ikke sikker på, at hans nevø egentlig hed Harry.
English: Come to think of it, he wasn’t even sure his nephew was called Harry.

Danish: Han havde jo heller aldrig set drengen. Det kunne være, at han hed Harvey. Eller Harold, måske.
English: He’d never even seen the boy. It might have been Harvey. Or Harold.

Danish: Der var ingen grund til at forurolige fru Dursley med dette. Hun blev altid så nervøs, når man nævnte hendes søster.
English: There was no point in worrying Mrs Dursley, she always got so upset at any mention of her sister.

Danish: Og han kunne ikke bebrejde hende det – hvis han havde haft en søster som hende ... men alligevel ... hvad med alle de kappeklædte mennesker?
English: He didn’t blame her – if he’d had a sister like that … but all the same, those people in cloaks …

Danish: Han havde betydelige vanskeligheder med at koncentrere sig om drilbor resten af eftermiddagen, og da han forlod bygningen klokken fem, var han stadig så opslugt af andre tanker, at han stødte direkte ind i en mand, der netop gik forbi døren.
English: He found it a lot harder to concentrate on drills that afternoon, and when he left the building at five o’clock, he was still so worried that he walked straight into someone just outside the door.

Danish: „Undskyld,“ mumlede han, idet den lille gamling snublede og var ved at falde.
English: ‘Sorry,’ he grunted, as the tiny old man stumbled and almost fell.

Danish: Så opdagede hr. Dursley, at manden bar en lilla kappe, og at han ikke lod til at være det mindste ked af at blive skubbet til på den måde.
English: It was a few seconds before Mr Dursley realised that the man was wearing a violet cloak. He didn’t seem at all upset at being almost knocked to the ground.

Danish: Tværtimod, hans ansigt flækkede i et bredt grin, og han talte med så høj, pibende en stemme, at forbipasserende stirrede: „Tænk ikke på det, min gode mand. Intet kan komme mig på tværs i dag!
English: On the contrary, his face split into a wide smile and he said in a squeaky voice that made passers-by stare: ‘Don’t be sorry, my dear sir, for nothing could upset me today!

Danish: Glæd dig, for nu er Du-ved-hvem endelig borte! Selv en Muggler som du burde fejre denne glædesdag!“
English: Rejoice, for You-Know-Who has gone at last! Even Muggles like yourself should be celebrating, this happy, happy day!’

Danish: Og så omfavnede den gamle mand hr. Dursley og gik sin vej.
English: And the old man hugged Mr Dursley around the middle and walked off.

Danish: Hr. Dursley stod som fastfrosset til stedet.
English: Mr Dursley stood rooted to the spot.

Danish: Han var blevet omfavnet af en fuldkommen fremmed!
English: He had been hugged by a complete stranger.

Danish: Han syntes også, at den gamle mand havde kaldt ham for en Muggler, hvad det end kunne være for noget.
English: He also thought he had been called a Muggle, whatever that was.

Danish: Han var rystet i sin grundvold og skyndte sig over til sin bil. Idet han kørte hjemad, forsøgte han håbefuldt at bilde sig ind, at han var begyndt at dagdrømme. Selv noget så tåbeligt som en livlig fantasi var at foretrække frem for, at alle disse underlige hændelser havde været den skinbarlige virkelighed.
English: He was rattled. He hurried to his car and set off home, hoping he was imagining things, which he had never hoped before, because he didn’t approve of imagination.

Danish: Da han var på vej ind ad sin indkørsel, var det første, han fik øje på, den stribede kat, han havde set samme morgen. Det gjorde ikke just hans humør bedre.
English: As he pulled into the driveway of number four, the first thing he saw – and it didn’t improve his mood – was the tabby cat he’d spotted that morning.

Danish: Nu sad den på hans havemur.
English: It was now sitting on his garden wall.

Danish: Han var sikker på, at det var den samme kat; den havde de samme markeringer omkring øjnene.
English: He was sure it was the same one; it had the same markings around its eyes.

Danish: „Væk med sig!“ råbte hr. Dursley højt.
English: ‘Shoo!’ said Mr Dursley loudly.

Danish: Katten bevægede sig ikke en tomme. Den så i stedet på ham med et strengt blik.
English: The cat didn’t move. It just gave him a stern look.

Danish: Var det normal katteadfærd? tænkte hr. Dursley.
English: Was this normal cat behaviour, Mr Dursley wondered.

Danish: Han låste sig ind i huset, mens han forsøgte at tage sig sammen og falde til ro. Han var stadig fast besluttet på ikke at sige noget til sin kone.
English: Trying to pull himself together, he let himself into the house. He was still determined not to mention anything to his wife.

Danish: Fru Dursley havde haft en ganske rar og normal dag.
English: Mrs Dursley had had a nice, normal day.

Danish: Da de spiste til middag, fortalte hun ham alt om naboens problemer med datteren, og hvordan Dudley havde lært et nyt udtryk („Vil-ikk!“).
English: She told him over dinner all about Mrs Next Door’s problems with her daughter and how Dudley had learnt a new word (‘Shan’t!’).

Danish: Hr. Dursley forsøgte at opføre sig helt normalt.
English: Mr Dursley tried to act normally.

Danish: Da Dudley var blevet lagt i seng, gik han ind i stuen og nåede lige at se de sene nyheder.
English: When Dudley had been put to bed, he went into the living-room in time to catch the last report on the evening news:

Danish: „Og til sidst kan vi meddele, at ornitologer overalt i landet har rapporteret om uglernes usædvanlige adfærd i dag.
English: ‘And finally, bird-watchers everywhere have reported that the nation’s owls have been behaving very unusually today.

Danish: Selvom ugler normalt jager om natten og kun sjældent ses i dagslys, har der været over hundrede rapporter om denne nattefugls hektiske aktivitet lige siden daggry.
English: Although owls normally hunt at night and are hardly ever seen in daylight, there have been hundreds of sightings of these birds flying in every direction since sunrise.

Danish: Eksperterne er ikke i stand til at forklare den drastiske ændring i fuglens døgnrytme.“
English: Experts are unable to explain why the owls have suddenly changed their sleeping pattern.’

Danish: Nyhedsoplæseren tillod sig at give seerne et skævt smil.
English: The news reader allowed himself a grin.

Danish: „Meget mystisk.
English: ‘Most mysterious.

Danish: Og nu over til Jim McGuffin med vejrudsigten.
English: And now, over to Jim McGuffin with the weather.

Danish: Skal vi have flere forvirrede ugler til at flyve omkring i det næste stykke tid, Jim?“
English: Going to be any more showers of owls tonight, Jim?’

Danish: „Tja, Ted,“ sagde meteorologen, „det kan jeg ikke svare på, men jeg kan fortælle, at det ikke kun er uglerne, som har været forvirrede i dag.
English: ‘Well, Ted,’ said the weatherman, ‘I don’t know about that, but it’s not only the owls that have been acting oddly today.

Danish: Seere fra nær og fjern har ringet ind for at rapportere, at de, i stedet for den regn, jeg lovede dem i går, har fået veritable byger af stjerneskud!
English: Viewers as far apart as Kent, Yorkshire and Dundee have been phoning in to tell me that instead of the rain I promised yesterday, they’ve had a downpour of shooting stars!

Danish: Måske har folk været ude for at fejre sankthans tidligt i år – men det er altså ikke før i næste uge, folkens!
English: Perhaps people have been celebrating Bonfire Night early – it’s not until next week, folks!

Danish: Men jeg kan love regn i nat og i de tidlige morgentimer.“
English: But I can promise a wet night tonight.’

Danish: Hr. Dursley sad lamslået i sin lænestol.
English: Mr Dursley sat frozen in his armchair.

Danish: Stjerneskud over hele England?
English: Shooting stars all over Britain?

Danish: Ugler, der flyver forvirrede omkring ved højlys dag?
English: Owls flying by daylight?

Danish: Mystiske kappeklædte mennesker overalt?
English: Mysterious people in cloaks all over the place?

Danish: Og så den hviskende sladren om en familie ved navn Potter ...
English: And a whisper, a whisper about the Potters …

Danish: Fru Dursley trådte ind i stuen med to kopper te.
English: Mrs Dursley came into the living-room carrying two cups of tea.

Danish: Det nyttede ikke noget. Han var nødt til at fortælle hende om det.
English: It was no good. He’d have to say something to her.

Danish: Han rømmede sig nervøst. „Øh, Petunia, min kære. Du har vel ikke hørt fra din søster for nylig?“
English: He cleared his throat nervously. ‘Er – Petunia, dear – you haven’t heard from your sister lately, have you?’

Danish: Som forventet så fru Dursley temmelig forskrækket og bebrejdende ud.
English: As he had expected, Mrs Dursley looked shocked and angry.

Danish: Når alt kom til alt, var de jo stiltiende blevet enige om at foregive, at hun slet ikke havde en søster.
English: After all, they normally pretended she didn’t have a sister.

Danish: „Nej,“ sagde hun skarpt. „Hvorfor?“
English: ‘No,’ she said sharply. ‘Why?’

Danish: „Det er de mærkeligste ting, man hører i nyhederne,“ mumlede hr. Dursley. „Ugler ... stjerneskud ... og så var der en masse underlige folk i byen i dag ...“
English: ‘Funny stuff on the news,’ Mr Dursley mumbled. ‘Owls … shooting stars … and there were a lot of funny-looking people in town today …’

Danish: „Og hvad så?“ vrissede fru Dursley.
English: ‘So?’ snapped Mrs Dursley.

Danish: „Jo, jeg tænkte bare ... at måske ... det havde noget med ... hende og hendes familie at gøre.“
English: ‘Well, I just thought … maybe … it was something to do with … you know … her lot.’

Danish: Fru Dursley nippede til sin te med rynkede bryn.
English: Mrs Dursley sipped her tea through pursed lips.

Danish: Hr. Dursley overvejede, om han turde fortælle hende, at han havde hørt navnet Potter blive nævnt. Han besluttede, at han hellere måtte lade være.
English: Mr Dursley wondered whether he dared tell her he’d heard the name ‘Potter’. He decided he didn’t dare.

Danish: I stedet sagde han, så henkastet som muligt, „Deres søn – han er vel omkring Dudleys alder, er han ikke?“
English: Instead he said, as casually as he could, ‘Their son – he’d be about Dudley’s age now, wouldn’t he?’

Danish: „Det vil jeg tro,“ svarede fru Dursley spidst.
English: ‘I suppose so,’ said Mrs Dursley stiffly.

Danish: „Hvad er det nu, han hedder? Howard, eller sådan noget?“
English: ‘What’s his name again? Howard, isn’t it?’

Danish: „Nej, Harry. Et ganske rædsomt og simpelt navn, hvis du spørger mig.“
English: ‘Harry. Nasty, common name, if you ask me.’

Danish: „Ja, ingen tvivl om det,“ sagde hr. Dursley med hjertet synkende i livet. „Jeg er fuldkommen enig.“
English: ‘Oh, yes,’ said Mr Dursley, his heart sinking horribly. ‘Yes, I quite agree.’

Danish: Han berørte ikke emnet mere den aften, og de gik op i seng.
English: He didn’t say another word on the subject as they went upstairs to bed.

Danish: Mens fru Dursley var ude på badeværelset, listede hr. Dursley hen til soveværelsets vindue og kiggede ud i forhaven.
English: While Mrs Dursley was in the bathroom, Mr Dursley crept to the bedroom window and peered down into the front garden.

Danish: Katten var der stadig.
English: The cat was still there.

Danish: Den stirrede ned ad Ligustervænget, som om den holdt øje med noget.
English: It was staring down Privet Drive as though it was waiting for something.

Danish: Var det hans fantasi, der spillede ham et puds?
English: Was he imagining things?

Danish: Hvordan kunne alt dette have nogen forbindelse til Potter-familien?
English: Could all this have anything to do with the Potters?

Danish: Hvis det kom ud ... hvis det blev opdaget, at de var i familie med sådan nogle – åh nej, han kunne slet ikke holde ud at tænke på det.
English: If it did … if it got out that they were related to a pair of – well, he didn’t think he could bear it.

Danish: Ægteparret Dursley gik i seng.
English: The Dursleys got into bed.

Danish: Fru Dursley faldt hurtigt i søvn, mens hr. Dursley lå vågen og spekulerede som en gal.
English: Mrs Dursley fell asleep quickly but Mr Dursley lay awake, turning it all over in his mind.

Danish: Hans sidste trøstende tanke, før han faldt i søvn, var, at selvom familien Potter var involveret, behøvede de jo ikke at belemre ham og fru Dursley med det.
English: His last, comforting thought before he fell asleep was that even if the Potters were involved, there was no reason for them to come near him and Mrs Dursley.

Danish: Potter-familien vidste udmærket godt, hvad Petunia og han mente om dem og deres slags ...
English: The Potters knew very well what he and Petunia thought about them and their kind …

Danish: Han kunne faktisk slet ikke se, hvordan Petunia og han kunne blive blandet ind i, hvad der end foregik.
English: He couldn’t see how he and Petunia could get mixed up in anything that might be going on.

Danish: Han gabte og vendte sig om på siden – det kom ikke dem ved ...
English: He yawned and turned over. It couldn’t affect them …

Danish: Men der tog han meget fejl.
English: How very wrong he was.

Danish: Hr. Dursley var døset hen i en urolig søvn, men katten udenfor på havemuren viste ingen tegn på træthed.
English: Mr Dursley might have been drifting into an uneasy sleep, but the cat on the wall outside was showing no sign of sleepiness.

Danish: Den sad stille som en statue med øjne, der uden at blinke var rettet mod svinget for enden af Ligustervænget.
English: It was sitting as still as a statue, its eyes fixed unblinkingly on the far corner of Privet Drive.

Danish: En bildør smækkede pludselig, men katten fortrak ikke en mine. Den lod sig heller ikke mærke med, at to ugler fløj tæt hen over hovedet på den.
English: It didn’t so much as quiver when a car door slammed in the next street, nor when two owls swooped overhead.

Danish: Faktisk var det næsten midnat, før den bevægede en muskel.
English: In fact, it was nearly midnight before the cat moved at all.

Danish: En mand kom gående nede i svinget, som katten så tålmodigt havde holdt øje med. Han kom så pludseligt til syne, at det nærmest virkede, som om han var sprunget ud af den blå luft.
English: A man appeared on the corner the cat had been watching, appeared so suddenly and silently you’d have thought he’d just popped out of the ground.

Danish: Kattens hale begyndte at piske, og dens øjne blev til smalle sprækker.
English: The cat’s tail twitched and its eyes narrowed.

Danish: En mand af denne støbning var aldrig før blevet set på Ligustervænget.
English: Nothing like this man had ever been seen in Privet Drive.

Danish: Han var høj, tynd og meget gammel, hvis man skulle dømme efter den sølvgrå farve på hans hår og skæg; begge dele var så langt, at det nåede ned til hans bælte.
English: He was tall, thin and very old, judging by the silver of his hair and beard, which were both long enough to tuck into his belt.

Danish: Han var i lange gevandter, en violet kappe, der slæbte hen ad jorden, og højhælede støvler med spænder.
English: He was wearing long robes, a purple cloak which swept the ground and high-heeled, buckled boots.

Danish: Hans blå øjne var lyse og strålende bag halvbrillerne, der sad på den lange høgenæse, som så ud til at have været brækket mindst et par gange.
English: His blue eyes were light, bright and sparkling behind half-moon spectacles and his nose was very long and crooked, as though it had been broken at least twice.

Danish: Mandens navn var Albus Dumbledore.
English: This man’s name was Albus Dumbledore.

Danish: Albus Dumbledore så ikke ud til at være klar over, at han færdedes i et kvarter, hvor mænd af hans slags var særdeles uvelkomne. Alt ved ham var forkert ifølge det uskrevne reglement – lige fra hans navn til de højhælede støvler med spænder. Men Albus Dumbledore var optaget af alt andet end sin persons anseelse.
English: Albus Dumbledore didn’t seem to realise that he had just arrived in a street where everything from his name to his boots was unwelcome.

Danish: Han rodede efter et eller andet i sin kappes lommer, men samtidig lod han dog til at være klar over, at han blev betragtet. Han løftede hovedet med et sæt og så direkte på katten, som stadig holdt øje med ham fra gadens anden ende.
English: He was busy rummaging in his cloak, looking for something. But he did seem to realise he was being watched, because he looked up suddenly at the cat, which was still staring at him from the other end of the street.

Danish: Af en eller anden grund lod synet af katten til at more ham.
English: For some reason, the sight of the cat seemed to amuse him.

Danish: Han kluklo og mumlede, „Det burde jeg have sagt mig selv.“
English: He chuckled and muttered, ‘I should have known.’

Danish: Endelig fandt han, hvad han ledte efter i en af lommerne. Det lignede en slags lighter af sølv.
English: He had found what he was looking for in his inside pocket. It seemed to be a silver cigarette lighter.

Danish: Han hævede den op i luften og klikkede på den.
English: He flicked it open, held it up in the air and clicked it.

Danish: Den nærmeste gadelygte gik ud med et lille knald.
English: The nearest street lamp went out with a little pop.

Danish: Han klikkede igen – den næste lygte gik ud, og det blev mørkt omkring den.
English: He clicked it again – the next lamp flickered into darkness.

Danish: Ikke mindre end tolv gange klikkede han på Slukkeren, indtil det eneste lys i hele gaden var to bittesmå prikker et stykke derfra. Det var kattens øjne, der stadig vogtede på ham.
English: Twelve times he clicked the Put-Outer, until the only lights left in the whole street were two tiny pinpricks in the distance, which were the eyes of the cat watching him.

Danish: Hvis nogen kiggede ud ad deres vindue i dette øjeblik, ville selv en så trænet iagttager som fru Dursley ikke være i stand til at se noget som helst nede på fortovet.
English: If anyone looked out of their window now, even beady-eyed Mrs Dursley, they wouldn’t be able to see anything that was happening down on the pavement.

Danish: Dumbledore puttede Slukkeren tilbage i lommen og begyndte at gå videre hen ad gaden mod nummer fire. Da han nåede frem, satte han sig ned på havemuren ved siden af katten.
English: Dumbledore slipped the Put-Outer back inside his cloak and set off down the street towards number four, where he sat down on the wall next to the cat.

Danish: Han kiggede ikke på den, men efter et øjeblik begyndte han at tale til den.
English: He didn’t look at it, but after a moment he spoke to it.

Danish: „Hvor morsomt at træffe Dem her, professor McGonagall.“
English: ‘Fancy seeing you here, Professor McGonagall.’

Danish: Han vendte sig for at smile til katten, men den var forsvundet.
English: He turned to smile at the tabby, but it had gone.

Danish: I stedet sad han og smilede til en temmelig stramtandet dame med firkantede brilleglas af nøjagtig samme form som den forsvundne kats markeringer omkring øjnene.
English: Instead he was smiling at a rather severe-looking woman who was wearing square glasses exactly the shape of the markings the cat had had around its eyes.

Danish: Hun var også klædt i en kappe, en smaragdgrøn en.
English: She, too, was wearing a cloak, an emerald one.

Danish: Hendes sorte hår var samlet i en knude i nakken, og hun så temmelig forbløffet ud.
English: Her black hair was drawn into a tight bun. She looked distinctly ruffled.

Danish: „Hvordan kunne du vide, at det var mig?“ spurgte hun.
English: ‘How did you know it was me?’ she asked.

Danish: „Min kære professor, jeg har aldrig set en kat sidde så stift og ubevægeligt.“
English: ‘My dear Professor, I’ve never seen a cat sit so stiffly.’

Danish: „Du ville også føle dig en smule stiv i lemmerne, hvis du havde siddet på en havemur hele dagen,“ svarede professor McGonagall.
English: ‘You’d be stiff if you’d been sitting on a brick wall all day,’ said Professor McGonagall.

Danish: „Hele dagen? Når du kunne have fejret og festet? Jeg tror, at jeg passerede mindst et dusin fester på vej hertil.“
English: ‘All day? When you could have been celebrating? I must have passed a dozen feasts and parties on my way here.’

Danish: Professor McGonagall gjorde en vred grimasse.
English: Professor McGonagall sniffed angrily.

Danish: „Åh, ja, alle fester jo af hjertens lyst,“ sagde hun utålmodigt.
English: ‘Oh yes, everyone’s celebrating, all right,’ she said impatiently.

Danish: „Man skulle ellers tro, at de ville være en smule forsigtige; men nej – selv Mugglerne har opdaget, at der er noget i gære.
English: ‘You’d think they’d be a bit more careful, but no – even the Muggles have noticed something’s going on.

Danish: De havde det med i nyhedsudsendelserne.“ Hun slog med hovedet i retning af Dursley-familiens mørke stuevindue.
English: It was on their news.’ She jerked her head back at the Dursleys’ dark living-room window.

Danish: „Jeg hørte det hele. Flokke af forvirrede ugler ... stjerneskud ... tja, de er jo ikke helt tabt bag af en vogn.
English: ‘I heard it. Flocks of owls … shooting stars … Well, they’re not completely stupid.

Danish: Det kunne ikke undgås, at de ville lægge mærke til noget.
English: They were bound to notice something.

Danish: Stjerneskud helt oppe i Kent – jeg tør vædde på, at det var Dedalus Diggle. Han har aldrig været for kløgtig.“
English: Shooting stars down in Kent – I’ll bet that was Dedalus Diggle. He never had much sense.’

Danish: „Du kan da ikke bebrejde dem noget,“ sagde Dumbledore venligt. „Vi har haft så lidt at glæde os over i de sidste elleve år.“
English: ‘You can’t blame them,’ said Dumbledore gently. ‘We’ve had precious little to celebrate for eleven years.’

Danish: „Det ved jeg godt,“ sagde professor McGonagall irriteret. „Men der er ingen grund til helt at miste jordforbindelsen.
English: ‘I know that,’ said Professor McGonagall irritably. ‘But that’s no reason to lose our heads.

Danish: Folk er jo direkte uforsigtige. De render omkring i gaderne ved højlys dag, og de er ikke engang klædt som Mugglerne. Det bliver der lagt mærke til.“
English: People are being downright careless, out on the streets in broad daylight, not even dressed in Muggle clothes, swapping rumours.’

Danish: Hun kastede et skarpt blik over på Dumbledore, som om hun ventede på, at han skulle fortælle hende noget, men han tav. Så fortsatte hun: „Det kunne have været kønt, hvis Mugglerne opdagede alt om os på selv samme dag, som Du-ved-hvem endelig synes at være forsvundet.
English: She threw a sharp, sideways glance at Dumbledore here, as though hoping he was going to tell her something, but he didn’t, so she went on: ‘A fine thing it would be if, on the very day You-Know-Who seems to have disappeared at last, the Muggles found out about us all.

Danish: Han er da virkelig borte, er han ikke, Dumbledore?“
English: I suppose he really has gone, Dumbledore?’

Danish: „Det lader i hvert fald til det,“ sagde Dumbledore. „Vi har meget at være taknemmelige for.
English: ‘It certainly seems so,’ said Dumbledore. ‘We have much to be thankful for.

Danish: Har du lyst til noget citronsorbet?“
English: Would you care for a sherbet lemon?’

Danish: „Til hvad?“
English: ‘A what?’

Danish: „Citronsorbet. Det er en Muggler-dessert, som jeg er blevet meget forfalden til.“
English: ‘A sherbet lemon. They’re a kind of Muggle sweet I’m rather fond of.’

Danish: „Nej, tak,“ sagde professor McGonagall køligt. Hun mente ikke, at tiden var inde til at nyde citronsorbet.
English: ‘No, thank you,’ said Professor McGonagall coldly, as though she didn’t think this was the moment for sherbet lemons.

Danish: „Som jeg sagde, selvom Du-ved-hvem virkelig er borte ...“
English: ‘As I say, even if You-Know-Who has gone –’

Danish: „Min kære professor. Et fornuftigt menneske som du burde virkelig være i stand til at kalde ham ved hans rette navn.
English: ‘My dear Professor, surely a sensible person like yourself can call him by his name?

Danish: Hvad skal vi med alt det Du-ved-hvem-nonsens. I elleve år har jeg forsøgt at overtale folk til at sige hans navn, som det er: Voldemort.“
English: All this “You-Know-Who” nonsense – for eleven years I have been trying to persuade people to call him by his proper name: Voldemort.’

Danish: Det gav et sæt i professor McGonagall, men Dumbledore var travlt optaget af at åbne et bæger citronsorbet og lagde ikke mærke til hendes reaktion.
English: Professor McGonagall flinched, but Dumbledore, who was unsticking two sherbet lemons, seemed not to notice.

Danish: „Det er så forvirrende, at vi bliver ved med at kalde ham Du-ved-hvem. Jeg kan ikke se, hvorfor det er så farligt at nævne Voldemorts navn.“
English: ‘It all gets so confusing if we keep saying “You-Know-Who”.’ I have never seen any reason to be frightened of saying Voldemort’s name.’

Danish: „Det ved jeg, at du ikke kan,“ sagde professor McGonagall og lød halvt fortvivlet og halvt beundrende. „Men du er også anderledes.
English: ‘I know you haven’t,’ said Professor McGonagall, sounding half-exasperated, half-admiring. ‘But you’re different.

Danish: Alle ved, at du er den eneste, som Du-ved – åh, så lad gå da – Voldemort nogensinde har frygtet.“
English: Everyone knows you’re the only one You-Know – oh, all right, Voldemort – was frightened of.’

Danish: „Du smigrer mig,“ sagde Dumbledore roligt. „Voldemort er i besiddelse af kræfter, jeg aldrig nogensinde vil få.“
English: ‘You flatter me,’ said Dumbledore calmly. ‘Voldemort had powers I will never have.’

Danish: „Kun fordi du er for hæderlig til at gøre brug af dem.“
English: ‘Only because you’re too – well – noble to use them.’

Danish: „Jeg er glad for, at her er så mørkt. Jeg har ikke rødmet sådan, siden madam Pomfrey betroede mig, at hun godt kunne lide mine nye ørevarmere.“
English: ‘It’s lucky it’s dark. I haven’t blushed so much since Madam Pomfrey told me she liked my new earmuffs.’

Danish: Professor McGonagall skævede til Dumbledore og sagde, „Uglerne er intet i sammenligning med de rygter, som svirrer omkring.
English: Professor McGonagall shot a sharp look at Dumbledore and said, ‘The owls are nothing to the rumours that are flying around.

Danish: Ved du, hvad alle går og siger? Om, hvorfor han er forsvundet? Om, hvad der endelig standsede ham?“
English: You know what everyone’s saying? About why he’s disappeared? About what finally stopped him?’

Danish: Det lod til, at hun endelig var nået frem til det, der lå hende mest på sinde; den egentlige årsag til, at hun havde siddet på en kold, hård havemur og ventet hele dagen. Hendes blik var pludselig så skarpt og gennemtrængende som nogen kats.
English: It seemed that Professor McGonagall had reached the point she was most anxious to discuss, the real reason she had been waiting on a cold hard wall all day, for neither as a cat nor as a woman had she fixed Dumbledore with such a piercing stare as she did now.

Danish: Hun ville åbenbart ikke lade sig nøje med svirrende rygter og havde ikke tænkt sig at tage stilling til, hvad der blev sagt, før Dumbledore havde fortalt hende sandheden.
English: It was plain that whatever ‘everyone’ was saying, she was not going to believe it until Dumbledore told her it was true.

Danish: Men Dumbledore, igen optaget af at spise citronsorbet, svarede ikke.
English: Dumbledore, however, was choosing another sherbet lemon and did not answer.

Danish: „De siger,“ fortsatte hun ufortrødent, „at Voldemort i går aftes viste sig i Godric-dalen for at finde Potter-familien.
English: ‘What they’re saying,’ she pressed on, ‘is that last night Voldemort turned up in Godric’s Hollow. He went to find the Potters.

Danish: Rygtet vil vide, at Lily og James Potter er ... er døde.“
English: The rumour is that Lily and James Potter are – are – that they’re – dead.’

Danish: Dumbledore bøjede sit hoved.
English: Dumbledore bowed his head.

Danish: Professor McGonagall gispede.
English: Professor McGonagall gasped.

Danish: „Lily og James ... det kan ikke være sandt ... jeg ønskede ikke at tro på det ... åh, Albus ...“
English: ‘Lily and James … I can’t believe it … I didn’t want to believe it … Oh, Albus …’

Danish: Dumbledore rakte ud og klappede hende på skulderen.
English: Dumbledore reached out and patted her on the shoulder.

Danish: „Jeg forstår det godt ... jeg forstår det kun alt for godt ...“ sagde han tungt.
English: ‘I know … I know …’ he said heavily.

Danish: Professor McGonagalls stemme sitrede, idet hun fortsatte: „Men det er ikke alt, hvad der siges.
English: Professor McGonagall’s voice trembled as she went on. ‘That’s not all.

Danish: Man påstår, at han har forsøgt at dræbe deres søn, Harry.
English: They’re saying he tried to kill the Potters’ son, Harry.

Danish: Men han gjorde det ikke. Han kunne ikke få bugt med den lille dreng.
English: But – he couldn’t. He couldn’t kill that little boy.

Danish: Ingen ved, hvordan det gik til, men man siger også, at da han fejlede i forsøget på at dræbe Harry Potter, blev Voldemorts magt brudt. Det er grunden til, at han forsvandt.“
English: No one knows why, or how, but they’re saying that when he couldn’t kill Harry Potter, Voldemort’s power somehow broke – and that’s why he’s gone.’

Danish: Dumbledore nikkede dystert.
English: Dumbledore nodded glumly.

Danish: „Er det ... er det sandt?“ stammede professor McGonagall.
English: ‘It’s – it’s true?’ faltered Professor McGonagall.

Danish: „Efter alt, hvad han har gjort ... alle de mennesker, han har slået ihjel ... så kunne han ikke dræbe en lille dreng?
English: ‘After all he’s done … all the people he’s killed … he couldn’t kill a little boy?

Danish: Det er forbløffende. Tænk, at en lille dreng kunne standse ham. Men hvordan i alverden kunne Harry dog klare sig?“
English: It’s just astounding … of all the things to stop him … but how in the name of heaven did Harry survive?’

Danish: „Det kan vi kun gisne om,“ sagde Dumbledore. „Måske får vi aldrig sandheden at vide.“
English: ‘We can only guess,’ said Dumbledore. ‘We may never know.’

Danish: Professor McGonagall trak et kniplingslommetørklæde frem og duppede sig under øjnene.
English: Professor McGonagall pulled out a lace handkerchief and dabbed at her eyes beneath her spectacles.

Danish: Dumbledore snøftede voldsomt, idet han fremdrog et guldur fra sin lomme og nøje studerede det.
English: Dumbledore gave a great sniff as he took a golden watch from his pocket and examined it.

Danish: Det var et meget mærkeligt ur; det havde tolv visere, men ingen tal. I stedet for tal var der små planeter, der bevægede sig rundt langs skivens kant.
English: It was a very odd watch. It had twelve hands but no numbers; instead, little planets were moving around the edge.

Danish: Øjensynligt kunne Dumbledore sagtens finde mening i, hvad urskiven viste, for han puttede uret tilbage i lommen og sagde, „Hagrid er sent på den.
English: It must have made sense to Dumbledore, though, because he put it back in his pocket and said, ‘Hagrid’s late.

Danish: Jeg går ud fra, at det var ham, der fortalte dig, at jeg ville være her, var det ikke?“
English: I suppose it was he who told you I’d be here, by the way?’

Danish: „Jo,“ sagde Professor McGonagall. „Men jeg regner ikke med, at du vil fortælle mig, hvorfor du befinder dig her af alle steder.“
English: ‘Yes,’ said Professor McGonagall. ‘And I don’t suppose you’re going to tell me why you’re here, of all places?’

Danish: „Jeg er kommet for at bringe Harry hjem til sin onkel og tante. De er hans sidste slægtninge nu.“
English: ‘I’ve come to bring Harry to his aunt and uncle. They’re the only family he has left now.’

Danish: „Det kan du ikke mene. Ikke de mennesker, der bor her, vel?“ udbrød professor McGonagall og sprang op, idet hun pegede på nummer fire. „Dumbledore – det kan du ikke nænne!
English: ‘You don’t mean – you can’t mean the people who live here?’ cried Professor McGonagall, jumping to her feet and pointing at number four. ‘Dumbledore – you can’t.

Danish: Jeg har holdt øje med dem hele dagen. Du kan ikke finde nogen mennesker, der ligner os mindre.
English: I’ve been watching them all day. You couldn’t find two people who are less like us.

Danish: Og de har denne her søn – jeg så ham sparke sin mor hele vejen op ad gaden, mens han skreg på slik. Skal Harry Potter virkelig udsættes for det?“
English: And they’ve got this son – I saw him kicking his mother all the way up the street, screaming for sweets. Harry Potter come and live here!’

Danish: „Det er det bedste sted for ham lige nu,“ sagde Dumbledore bestemt. „Hans onkel og tante vil kunne forklare ham alting, når han bliver ældre. Jeg har skrevet et brev til dem.“
English: ‘It’s the best place for him,’ said Dumbledore firmly. ‘His aunt and uncle will be able to explain everything to him when he’s older. I’ve written them a letter.’

Danish: „Et brev?“ sagde Professor McGonagall skeptisk og lænede sig tilbage mod havemuren.
English: ‘A letter?’ repeated Professor McGonagall faintly, sitting back down on the wall.

Danish: „Hør nu her, Dumbledore. Tror du virkelig, at du er i stand til at forklare alt dette i et brev?
English: ‘Really, Dumbledore, you think you can explain all this in a letter?

Danish: De mennesker vil aldrig kunne forstå ham!
English: These people will never understand him!

Danish: Han bliver berømt en dag – en levende legende. Jeg ville ikke blive forbavset, hvis dagen i dag bliver udråbt til Harry Potter-dagen. Man vil skrive bøger om Harry. Alle børn i hele verden vil lære hans navn at kende!“
English: He’ll be famous – a legend – I wouldn’t be surprised if today was known as Harry Potter Day in future – there will be books written about Harry – every child in our world will know his name!’

Danish: „Lige præcis,“ sagde Dumbledore og kiggede meget alvorligt ud over sine halvbriller.
English: ‘Exactly,’ said Dumbledore, looking very seriously over the top of his half-moon glasses.

Danish: „Den slags er jo nok til at gøre enhver dreng helt forskruet.
English: ‘It would be enough to turn any boy’s head.

Danish: Berømt, før han kan gå eller tale!
English: Famous before he can walk and talk!

Danish: Berømt for noget, han end ikke vil kunne huske!
English: Famous for something he won’t even remember!

Danish: Kan du ikke se, at det vil være bedre, hvis han vokser op et sted, hvor ingen kender ham, indtil han er gammel nok til at få historien fortalt?“
English: Can’t you see how much better off he’ll be, growing up away from all that until he’s ready to take it?’

Danish: Professor McGonagall åbnede munden, som om hun ville sige noget, men tænkte sig om en ekstra gang, før hun talte. Så sagde hun, „Ja, naturligvis. Du har ret. Men hvordan vil du få bragt drengen hertil, Dumbledore?“
English: Professor McGonagall opened her mouth, changed her mind, swallowed and then said, ‘Yes – yes, you’re right, of course. But how is the boy getting here, Dumbledore?’

Danish: Hun stirrede undersøgende på hans kappe, som om hun mistænkte ham for at have drengen gemt et sted inde mellem folderne.
English: She eyed his cloak suddenly as though she thought he might be hiding Harry underneath it.

Danish: „Hagrid kommer med ham.“
English: ‘Hagrid’s bringing him.’

Danish: „Tror du, det er ... klogt at betro Hagrid sådan en vigtig opgave?“
English: ‘You think it – wise – to trust Hagrid with something as important as this?’

Danish: „Jeg ville ikke tøve med at lægge mit liv i hænderne på Hagrid,“ sagde Dumbledore.
English: ‘I would trust Hagrid with my life,’ said Dumbledore.

Danish: „Jeg siger jo heller ikke, at hans hjerte ikke er på rette sted,“ indvendte professor McGonagall stødt, „men du må da indrømme, at han er lidt sløset. Han har en tendens til at – hør, hvad var det?“
English: ‘I’m not saying his heart isn’t in the right place,’ said Professor McGonagall grudgingly, ‘but you can’t pretend he’s not careless. He does tend to – what was that?’

Danish: En sagte rumlende lyd brød stilheden omkring dem.
English: A low rumbling sound had broken the silence around them.

Danish: Den blev højere og højere, idet de kiggede op og ned ad gaden for at få øje på nogle forlygter. Lyden steg til en brølen, da de løftede blikket mod himlen og så en kæmpemæssig motorcykel komme til syne fra højderne og lande på fortovet ved siden af dem.
English: It grew steadily louder as they looked up and down the street for some sign of a headlight; it swelled to a roar as they both looked up at the sky – and a huge motorbike fell out of the air and landed on the road in front of them.

Danish: Hvis motorcyklen var enorm, var den alligevel intet i sammenligning med manden, der sad på den.
English: If the motorbike was huge, it was nothing to the man sitting astride it.

Danish: Han var næsten dobbelt så høj som en normal mand og mindst fem gange så bred.
English: He was almost twice as tall as a normal man and at least five times as wide.

Danish: Man skulle ganske enkelt mene, at han var større, end det burde være tilladt, og i tilgift lignede han også en vildmand med langt, viltert sort hår og et skæg, der næsten skjulte hele hans ansigt. Han havde hænder så store som skinker, og hans fødder, klædt i solide motorcykelstøvler, var på størrelse med små delfiner.
English: He looked simply too big to be allowed, and so wild – long tangles of bushy black hair and beard hid most of his face, he had hands the size of dustbin lids and his feet in their leather boots were like baby dolphins.

Danish: I sine mægtige, muskuløse arme holdt han en bylt indsvøbt i tæpper.
English: In his vast, muscular arms he was holding a bundle of blankets.

Danish: „Hagrid,“ sagde Dumbledore lettet. „Endelig.
English: ‘Hagrid,’ said Dumbledore, sounding relieved. ‘At last.

Danish: Og sig mig, hvor fik du fat i den motorcykel?“
English: And where did you get that motorbike?’

Danish: „Jeg lånte den, professor Dumbledore,“ sagde kæmpen og steg forsigtigt af sit køretøj. „Unge Sirius Black var så venlig at lade mig bruge den.
English: ‘Borrowed it, Professor Dumbledore, sir,’ said the giant, climbing carefully off the motorbike as he spoke. ‘Young Sirius Black lent it me.

Danish: Og jeg har Harry her, hr. professor.“
English: I’ve got him, sir.’

Danish: „Gik det hele glat?“
English: ‘No problems, were there?’

Danish: „Ja, hr. professor. Huset var næsten helt ødelagt, men jeg fik ham ud, før Mugglerne begyndte at myldre omkring os.
English: ‘No, sir – house was almost destroyed but I got him out all right before the Muggles started swarmin’ around.

Danish: Han faldt i søvn, da vi fløj over Bristol.“
English: He fell asleep as we was flyin’ over Bristol.’

Danish: Dumbledore og professor McGonagall bøjede sig frem for at se nærmere på bylten i Hagrids favn.
English: Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall bent forward over the bundle of blankets.

Danish: En drengs lille ansigt kunne lige skimtes mellem tæpperne. Han sov fast.
English: Inside, just visible, was a baby boy, fast asleep.

Danish: Han havde kulsort hår, og på panden kunne de se et mærkeligt ar med en facon som et lyn, der slår ned.
English: Under a tuft of jet-black hair over his forehead they could see a curiously shaped cut, like a bolt of lightning.

Danish: „Er det der, hvor ...?“ hviskede professor McGonagall
English: ‘Is that where –?’ whispered Professor McGonagall.

Danish: „Ja,“ sagde Dumbledore.
English: ‘Yes,’ said Dumbledore.

Danish: „Han vil altid have det ar.“
English: ‘He’ll have that scar for ever.’

Danish: „Kan du ikke gøre noget ved det, Dumbledore?“
English: ‘Couldn’t you do something about it, Dumbledore?’

Danish: „Selv, hvis jeg kunne, ville jeg ikke gøre noget.
English: ‘Even if I could, I wouldn’t.

Danish: Ar kan være ganske nyttige. Jeg har selv et over mit venstre knæ, og det er et komplet kort over Londons undergrundsbaner.
English: Scars can come in useful. I have one myself above my left knee which is a perfect map of the London Underground.

Danish: Nå, giv ham bare til mig, Hagrid. Vi må hellere få det overstået.“
English: Well – give him here, Hagrid – we’d better get this over with.’

Danish: Dumbledore tog Harry i sine arme og vendte sig mod familien Dursleys hus.
English: Dumbledore took Harry in his arms and turned towards the Dursleys’ house.

Danish: „Må jeg – må jeg have lov til at sige farvel til ham, hr. professor?“ spurgte Hagrid.
English: ‘Could I – could I say goodbye to him, sir?’ asked Hagrid.

Danish: Han bøjede sit store vildmandshoved ind over Harry og gav ham et rigtig skægget smækkys.
English: He bent his great, shaggy head over Harry and gave him what must have been a very scratchy, whiskery kiss.

Danish: Så rettede han sig op og udstødte et hyl som en såret hund.
English: Then, suddenly, Hagrid let out a howl like a wounded dog.

Danish: „Shhh!“ sagde professor McGonagall vredt. „Du vækker alle Mugglerne!“
English: ‘Shhh!’ hissed Professor McGonagall. ‘You’ll wake the Muggles!’

Danish: „U-u-undskyld,“ hulkede Hagrid og fandt et stort polkaprikket lommetørklæde frem, som han kunne begrave sit ansigt i.
English: ‘S-s-sorry,’ sobbed Hagrid, taking out a large spotted handkerchief and burying his face in it.

Danish: „Men jeg k-k-ka’ ikke holde det ud. Lilly og James er døde – og stakkels lille Harry ska’ bo hos Mugglerne ...“
English: ‘But I c-c-can’t stand it – Lily an’ James dead – an’ poor little Harry off ter live with Muggles –’

Danish: „Ja, jeg ved det godt. Det er alt sammen meget trist, men tag dig sammen, Hagrid. Ellers kommer der nogen og opdager os,“ hviskede professor McGonagall og klappede blidt Hagrid på armen, mens Dumbledore gik hen over græsplænen mod hoveddøren til nummer fire.
English: ‘Yes, yes, it’s all very sad, but get a grip on yourself, Hagrid, or we’ll be found,’ Professor McGonagall whispered, patting Hagrid gingerly on the arm as Dumbledore stepped over the low garden wall and walked to the front door.

Danish: Han lagde forsigtigt Harry ned ved dørtrinet, fandt et brev i lommen på sin kappe og stoppede det ind under Harrys tæpper. Så vendte han tilbage til de to andre.
English: He laid Harry gently on the doorstep, took a letter out of his cloak, tucked it inside Harry’s blankets and then came back to the other two.

Danish: I et helt minut stod de alle tre og betragtede den lille bylt på dørtrinet;
English: For a full minute the three of them stood and looked at the little bundle;

Danish: Hagrids skuldre rystede, professor McGonagall blinkede som en rasende med øjnene, og Dumbledores ellers så skarpe blik så ud til at være sløret.
English: Hagrid’s shoulders shook, Professor McGonagall blinked furiously and the twinkling light that usually shone from Dumbledore’s eyes seemed to have gone out.

Danish: „Tja,“ sagde Dumbledore endelig, „det var det.
English: ‘Well,’ said Dumbledore finally, ‘that’s that.

Danish: Vi bør ikke blive her længere.
English: We’ve no business staying here.

Danish: Vi kan vel lige så godt tage af sted og være med i festlighederne.“
English: We may as well go and join the celebrations.’

Danish: „Jah,“ sagde Hagrid med grødet stemme, „Jeg vil i hvert fald bringe Sirius’ motorcykel tilbage til ham.
English: ‘Yeah,’ said Hagrid in a very muffled voice. ‘I’d best get this bike away.

Danish: G’nat, professor McGonagall og hr. professor Dumbledore.“
English: G’night, Professor McGonagall – Professor Dumbledore, sir.’

Danish: Hagrid svang sig op på motorcyklen og tørrede sine tårefyldte øjne i ærmet. Han sparkede motoren i gang og lod køretøjet accelerere brølende op mod nattehimlen.
English: Wiping his streaming eyes on his jacket sleeve, Hagrid swung himself on to the motorbike and kicked the engine into life; with a roar it rose into the air and off into the night.

Danish: „Vi ses vel snart, professor McGonagall,“ sagde Dumbledore og nikkede til hende.
English: ‘I shall see you soon, I expect, Professor McGonagall,’ said Dumbledore, nodding to her.

Danish: Professor McGonagall pudsede næse som svar.
English: Professor McGonagall blew her nose in reply.

Danish: Dumbledore vendte sig og begyndte at gå tilbage mod hjørnet af Ligustervænget, hvorfra han var kommet. Han standsede midt i svinget og tog Slukkeren frem.
English: Dumbledore turned and walked back down the street. On the corner he stopped and took out the silver Put-Outer.

Danish: Han klikkede en enkelt gang, og alle tolv gadelygter tændtes med det samme og badede hele gaden i et orange lys. Nu kunne han tydeligt se den stribede kat forsvinde nede ved den anden ende af gaden.
English: He clicked it once and twelve balls of light sped back to their street lamps so that Privet Drive glowed suddenly orange and he could make out a tabby cat slinking around the corner at the other end of the street.

Danish: Han kunne også lige skimte bylten, der lå på det øverste trappetrin foran nummer fires hoveddør.
English: He could just see the bundle of blankets on the step of number four.

Danish: „Held og lykke, Harry,“ mumlede han.
English: ‘Good luck, Harry,’ he murmured.

Danish: Han drejede om på hælen, svang sin kappe omkring sig og var borte.
English: He turned on his heel and with a swish of his cloak he was gone.

Danish: En brise strøg gennem de nydeligt trimmede hække på Ligustervænget, som lå stille og velordnet under den kulsorte himmel; det sidste sted i verden, man ville forvente, at fantastiske ting skulle finde sted.
English: A breeze ruffled the neat hedges of Privet Drive, which lay silent and tidy under the inky sky, the very last place you would expect astonishing things to happen.

Danish: Harry Potter vendte sig i sine tæpper uden at vågne.
English: Harry Potter rolled over inside his blankets without waking up.

Danish: Han havde sin lille hånd lukket omkring brevet og sov trygt i komplet uvidenhed om, at han var noget ganske særligt, at han var berømt, og at han ville blive vækket af fru Dursleys skrig, når hun åbnede døren for at sætte mælkeflaskerne ud ... ej heller vidste han, at han de følgende år skulle finde sig i at blive knebet og skubbet af sin fætter Dudley.
English: One small hand closed on the letter beside him and he slept on, not knowing he was special, not knowing he was famous, not knowing he would be woken in a few hours’ time by Mrs Dursley’s scream as she opened the front door to put out the milk bottles, nor that he would spend the next few weeks being prodded and pinched by his cousin Dudley …

Danish: Han kunne ikke vide, at i dette øjeblik samledes folk i hemmelighed over hele landet for med dæmpede stemmer at udbringe Harry Potters skål: „Lad os tømme vores glas til ære for Harry Potter – drengen, der ikke kunne slås ihjel!“
English: He couldn’t know that at this very moment, people meeting in secret all over the country were holding up their glasses and saying in hushed voices: ‘To Harry Potter – the boy who lived!’
